questions.question: The SDLC phase where stakeholder needs are gathered and documented.
questions.explanation: Requirements Analysis involves collecting and documenting what stakeholders need from the software system.

questions.question: The SDLC phase where system architecture and technical specifications are created.
questions.explanation: The Design phase translates requirements into technical blueprints including architecture, database schemas, and interface designs.

questions.question: The SDLC phase where developers write the actual source code.
questions.explanation: Implementation is the coding phase where the design is converted into executable software.

questions.question: The SDLC phase where software is checked for bugs and verified against requirements.
questions.explanation: Testing verifies that software works correctly and meets the specified requirements.

questions.question: The SDLC phase where software is released to the production environment.
questions.explanation: Deployment is when tested software is installed and made available to end users.

questions.question: The SDLC phase focused on bug fixes and updates after release.
questions.explanation: Maintenance involves ongoing support, bug fixes, and enhancements after software deployment.

questions.question: An SDLC model that follows a linear sequential flow through all phases.
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model progresses linearly through each phase without returning to previous stages.

questions.question: An SDLC model that emphasizes iterative development and customer collaboration.
questions.explanation: Agile focuses on short iterations, continuous feedback, and adapting to changing requirements.

questions.question: An SDLC model where testing phases correspond to each development phase.
questions.explanation: The V-Model pairs each development stage with a corresponding testing phase for verification and validation.

questions.question: An SDLC model that incorporates risk analysis in each iteration.
questions.explanation: The Spiral model combines iterative development with systematic risk assessment at each cycle.
